Non-dominated sorting genetic algorithm (NSGA-III)

NSGA3 - Non-dominated sorting genetic algorithm

class glennopt.optimizers.nsga3.NSGA3(eval_command: str = 'python evaluation.py', eval_folder: str = 'Evaluation', pop_size: int = 128, optimization_folder: Optional[str] = None, single_folder_eval=False)[source]
__associate_to_niche__(fitnesses, reference_points, best_point, intercepts)[source]

Associates individuals to reference points and calculates niche number. Corresponds to Algorithm 3 of Deb & Jain (2014).

__find_extreme_points__(fitnesses, best_point, extreme_points=None)[source]

Finds the individuals with extreme values for each objective function. These definitions need to be updated. I used to know all this.

Parameters

  • fitnesses ([ndarray]) – how close individuals are to best point.1

  • best_point ([ndarray]) – array containing the best points

  • extreme_points ([ndarray], optional) – Points on the extreme of either objective 1 or objective 2. Defaults to None.

Returns

fitness of individuals. Description needs update

Return type

ndarray

__optimize__(individuals: List[glennopt.base.individual.Individual], n_generations: int, pop_start: int, reference_points: numpy.ndarray)[source]

NSGA-III main loop Note: This function will read given starting population’s results in, perform necessary crossover and mutation to generate enough individuals for the next iteration (self.pop_size)

Inputs:

individuals - list of individuals to evaluate n_generations - number of generations to loop through pop_start - starting population number

optimize_from_population(pop_start: int, n_generations: int)[source]

Reads the values of a population, this can be a DOE or a previous evaluation Starts the optimization

Inputs:

pop_start (-1 for DOE), reads the population folder and starts at pop_start+1 n_generations - number of generations to run for

sort_and_select_population(individuals: List[glennopt.base.individual.Individual], reference_points: numpy.ndarray)[source]

Takes a list of individuals, finds the fronts and the best designs

Code is a combination from deap and yarpiz https://github.com/DEAP https://yarpiz.com/456/ypea126-nsga3

Parameters

  • individuals (List[Individual]) – List of individuals from a DOE or POP or anything really

  • reference_points (np.ndarray) – reference points along the pareto front.

Raises

Exception – something bad has happened

Returns

containing

chosen (List[List[int]]): individuals along front in order of best to worst front best_point (int): index of best individual worst_point (int): index of worst individual extreme_points (List[int]): indexies of the extreme point

Return type

(tuple)

start_doe(doe_individuals: Optional[List[glennopt.base.individual.Individual]] = None, doe_size: int = 128)[source]

Starts a design of experiments. This generates the parameters for the individuals to be evaluated and executes each case. If the DOE has already started and there is an output file for an individual then the individual won’t be evaluated

Parameters

  • doe_individuals (List[Individual], optional) – List of individuals. Defaults to None.

  • doe_size (int, optional) – [description]. Defaults to 128.

uniform_reference_points(nobj, p=4, scaling=None)[source]

Generate reference points uniformly on the hyperplane intersecting each axis at 1. The scaling factor is used to combine multiple layers of reference points.

Parameters

  • nobj (int) – number of objectives

  • p (int, optional) – number of references per objective. Defaults to 4.

  • scaling ([type], optional) – [description]. Defaults to None.

glennopt.optimizers.nsga3.random() → x in the interval [0, 1).
